author: Mudella green
title: Mental Health services
body:
I was hospitalised in a mental health unit last year. This was my first experience with the mental health service and what an experience it was. After six months of dealing with life and all its stresses my mental health issues began, with me losing a friend that was very close to me. Everything came to a boil in early March last year.  
I was put on a ward on a Saturday night - that was my first contact with mental health services. I was very confused initially and didn't know where I was. There are a lot of things that I wasn't aware of.  
After about four to five days, I started to come back to myself. I was taken off the medication prescribed by my GP, which I had an allergic reaction to and I misused as well, none of which helped my situation. I was on this medication for less than a month but it was hell.  
When I arrived at the hospital I was in psychosis. I asked staff questions, only to find out that none of them were permanent members of staff and had no access to information. This went on for most of my stay in hospital - me asking for information and getting nowhere. I understood that we were patients in a mental institution. But we were still human beings with lives and responsibility outside of the hospital unit. There was no information that was accessible to the patients. Not even about your own care.  
We had review meetings about our care where we could ask questions of the managers but we never knew when or what time our reviews would be. This was very frustrating. Think about it. You've gone from being able to arrange your own appointments, having access to your own things to a situation where you have to ask for everything. Even the simplest of things like going out for a walk you needed permission for. For someone that's always been in control of their life this was very difficult. As the weeks went by it became even harder to make sense of it all. If you were awake before 11:00 there was nothing to do in the mornings. This I found very confusing and there was a lack of support.  
When I spoke to members of members of staff I was told to go to the office or they would get back to me in 10 minutes. Sometime days later they still had no information. The days became very long and dreary and depressing. You were left to think about all the things in your life that had gone wrong which does not help when you are having a mental breakdown.  
I was on a female ward and on two occasions male patients from other wards broke into the female wards and were able to walk around the ward past women's bedrooms. Members of staff were very slow to react and sometimes had little power to do anything. I was awake when both of these incidents occurred, lucky me. I must say there were staff members that would do everything that they could to help patients especially during the daytime. But weekends and night were the worst part of my stay.  
My biggest problem was the lack of communication. Between the staff members and patients also between staff members and management. When I had my review meetings there was basic information that was lacking from my file. It took them almost a month to get my address correct. There was just a breakdown in communication. This went on even after I was discharged from hospital. I had to be the one to be phoning the community mental health team to get them on board asking questions about my care or lack of care at the time. I found the crisis team was a joke. In the end I emailed everyone that I could reach, apologising for spelling mistakes in the e-mail, but I was able to get my point across.  
After everything that had happened I was left feeling confused, frustrated and angry. Patients had to call the doctors to get the care needed now looking back. I can see that you have fight for everything no matter what circumstances you're in.  
I am grateful for my stay in hospital. It helped me to start dealing a with the past. If I hadn't been admitted this would not have happened. Yes, I was given a psychologist and was helped by an amazing support worker.  
The service was suspended back in December so I have been put on another waiting list. But I have a better understanding of my mental health - how I got to where I was this time last year. For that I will forever be grateful to the mental health service, it has given me the space and time to deal with my past.  
It is now up to the one year anniversary of my stay in hospital. I am grateful for the help that I was given. Yes, it wasn't all good. But they have some amazing people working in the mental health service. It's just a shame there is a lack of support for them and for the patients in general.  
Thank you NHS

author: Shagq75
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Male medical ward is top class
body:
I like that the ward is kept at a comfortable temperature and that if you become a little chilly, you can just hide under the blankets in bed. My daily pattern is rather odd, I don't usually take naps, yet I frequently find myself dozing off during the day.  
The staff, they are specialists in their fields and are very knowledgeable. I don't feel stupid because of the way they explain things to me, and I am certain that any questions I have will be answered accurately and honestly. They must genuinely enjoy working here because the pressure they are under would kill some people.  
Male medical is top class.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: lacertajy64
title: MRI cancellation
body:
I was referred for a MRI by the gynaecology consultant at Wishaw General hospital in July 2022. I called today to see where I was on the list to be told I've been taken off the list. They wrote to the medical secretary in January 2023, got no reply, and then again in February - again no reply.  
They were asking for bloods to be done before they could do the MRI and because they got no response I've been taken off the list and been told when they refer me again I will go down to the bottom of the list. I need this MRI scan done before I can be seen at the complex mesh clinic in Glasgow and I am nearly at the top of their list to be seen.  
I'm extremely upset by this as it's through no fault of my own that this has happened - why should I be punished for an error by a staff member?

author: Wuzzle
title: Telephone message
body: I cannot fault the surgery staff in anyway here. What I do object to is paying to listen to a THREE MINUTE unnecessary message before being connected to the surgery. In this lean times I do not appreciate spending extra money on a long phone call. I think they should drop the gentleman (who you can’t actually hear anyway).

author: millimeterge86
title: Treatment of my elderly mother
body:
My mother is in her nineties, blind, hard of hearing and very frail. Ever since she has lived in Harlow she has received such a very poor standard of service from the Barbara Castle Health Centre. Every time I visit the surgery on her behalf (there is little point in ringing) the waiting room is empty. Yesterday however it was crowded with three patients waiting to see the doctor. 8 weeks ago she fell at home and broke her hip. She has been back home recovering for the last 4 weeks.  
I explained to the receptionist ( a very helpful person). that my mother had a urinary problem and was losing weight and was so weak she could barely stand. I asked for a home visit to be made and she said she would arrange it. Later in the day the doctor rang to say that they did not want to visit. My mother's sister in law insisted so they reluctantly agreed to visit without specifying a time. Later we were informed that it would be a paramedic. No one turned up.  
Unlike the many times before when diagnosis was made over the telephone, my family refused to accept this. The following day another appointment for a visit was made. It is such hard work. I simply do not understand the reluctance of GP's nowadays to actually meet their patients in person.

author: RachelR
title: GP system affecting my mental health
body:
They do a telephone only triage system here. Just like in covid, stop patients seeing a GP and I need to see a GP on regular basis to get OK.  
No medication review for over 2 years. Triggering mental health symptoms trying to phone , just thinking about it makes me physically sick. Wait hours on line then turned away as no slots. Asking for help and all I hear when they do this is 'go away, we don't want people like you'.  
To be safe with mental health, I need to see a GP. Telephone appointment system just made me so much worse.

author: march9th
title: Unhelpful GP service
body:
My husband recently had his gall bladder removed in Abu Dhabi (amazing treatment). Last week he had a pancreatitis recurrence and was hospitalized in Basingstoke ( pretty good treatment here). They asked for him to get repeat blood tests on Monday at home. We got a face to face appointment on the Monday.  
You need your blood pressure taken they said - we don't do that her, go to a pharmacy. So a gp has no equipment with which to spend a minute taking a blood pressure? What if the pharmacy said it was not good? Go and see your GP.... Utter nonsense.  
We don't sort blood test here - go home and log in. Which we did and booked it at the same practice for Friday - a whole eek after the hospital requested it. More nonsense. What if we had no internet or laptop?  
No wonder there is disquiet about the nhs. These sort of things are just rubbish.  
The phone line is no better giving info that is clearly out of date - eg your appointment will be only via telephone.  
Seriously not good enough.

author: empathybd57
title: Not happy at how I was treated
body:
Attended a GP referral today for an X-Ray at a drop in clinic at the imaging department in the New Victoria Hospital.  
Attended the department at 10 am. Was told it was a 30-40 minute wait - which was fine.  
Had been waiting for 1.5 hrs, so went up to the receptionist to ask if they knew roughly how much longer I would be waiting as people were coming and going and I was still waiting.  
Receptionist stated that I had only been in the department for an hour as they clocked me in at 10:25 am, even though I had checked in at 10 am. The receptionist stated that this is how they do things, and as I was only checked in for an hour on their system I would have to take a seat and there were 4 people ahead of me.  
Time went on and I was still sitting at 12 pm (2 hours after I arrived/ checked in) so again politely asked the receptionist if it would be much longer, as my daughter was waiting in the car for me for the 2 hours. Receptionist phoned through and was talking to the radiographer on the phone in-front of me discussing the situation, stating I had only been in the department for 1.25 hrs. When I corrected them saying that I was here for 2 hours, they replied back with attitude and said to take a seat and I would be taken next.  
I got my scan after 2 hrs and 25 mins of waiting.  
When the radiographer came to collect me from the waiting area, they said with attitude that they understood that I had been waiting and will need to just wait in this other area until this other patient was took.  
I am thankful that we have the NHS and that I got my scan. I don’t mind waiting my turn as I did. I’m just not happy at how I was treated during my visit to the hospital.  
There was no patient-centred care or compassion shown to myself, I was just another number waiting to be seen. The staff that spoke to me, especially the receptionist, was not pleasant to communicate with and communicated with attitude.

author: indigogj98
title: A&E unsafe for suicidal people
body:
I went to Addenbrooke’s A&E on a Friday at about 19:30. I told the triage nurse I was suicidal, and they let me in. After a while I was interviewed by a nurse, who I told I was suicidal, and that I had sorted out enough prescription drugs to take a fatal overdose before going to the hospital. I’m in a high-risk group, I’ve had a nearly-fatal suicide attempt before, and my plan was realistic and partially completed. The nurse told me that they would get someone from the psychiatry department to talk to me.  
At 22:20 I was called to speak to a nurse, who instructed me to go home because there were no staff from the psychiatry department working overnight. I expressed my surprise and dissatisfaction. The nurse advised me to try 111 option 2 if if was still ill. This is despite the fact that the NHS website tells you to go to A&E if you do not feel you can keep yourself safe and that a mental health emergency should be taken as seriously as a physical one. You will not be wasting anyone's time.  
I was still suicidal.

author: Tractor Bert
title: A truly excellent medical service
body:
Attended the New Victoria Infirmary for a rather invasive procedure - with a lot of personal concerns about how the whole procedure would evolve. First concern was trying to get parked as the clock ticked towards appointment time - how do management really expect you to check in relaxed and with your blood pressure at an acceptable level to operate? After eventually finding a parking space, life got a lot better - as the building has cheery volunteers at the front door to guide you to the correct unit.  
After checking in at reception (very pleasant staff) the nursing staff were outstanding - professional, cheery and re-assuring. Nurse Jean was everything you could wish for in a nursing professional - she made the whole challenging experience very positive and instinctively know how to deal with this rather nervous and concerned patient. Along with the other nurses in the day care surgical unit (and I hope their NHS choir experience is a real success), this team don't just talk about excellence they are delivering it to patients.  
Once in theatre itself, the surgical team displayed a superb blend of expertise, experience and re-assurance - plus an ability to communicate with me using easily understood vocabulary - I really appreciated this skill. This experience was not something I had been looking forward to but the NHS delivered a superb service and made me feel really looked after.  
I have zero criticism of the medical, admin or support staff at the New Victoria Infirmary - the hygiene and housekeeping standards also appeared to be of the highest standards.  
Thank you to the NHS team for delivering a truly excellent medical service to this patient - now to recuperate and get on with life. I have had a few days to reflect on what I've been through, so this review has been well thought through and I stand by the content. My only criticism of the day is aimed at politicians who think sick people should travel on unreliable and inconvenient public transport to hospital (and probably miss their appointment).

readBy.name: East Renfrewshire Health & Social Care Partnership

author: Tersg66
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: The care I am being given has been amazing
body:
I have been in and out of hospital since June. I have been in RVH and CAH. I have been in DHH about 6 weeks now. The staff on the Stroke and rehab ward are great. They are very helpful and very accommodating.  
The ward is great. The cleaning staff are very good. They have the ward shining.  
The food isn’t too bad, but this week the food hasn’t been the best. A few days this week the food has come up and it hasn’t been overly hot. But it is like everything in life, there will always be mishaps. For the most part, the food has been good.  
I am not sleeping great. The ward is very busy and can be slightly noisy at night but that comes with the nature of a hospital. It never stops.  
The care I am being given in Daisy hill has been amazing though.  
The physio is very helpful. The physiotherapists are very good and have a lot of patience.  
I am just waiting on a care package being put in place to get home now.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Tersg66
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: First class staff
body:
I came in to Daisy Hill at the start of the year. I came in to hospital after having a bad fall. And have been in stroke/rehab ever since.  
The staff on this ward are amazing. However, they are overworked and most definitely underpaid.  
The staff tend to get a lot of unwarranted bad manners from some patients which I think is totally unacceptable. They do their best and do not deserve the disrespect they get. They are amazing workers and go over and above to look after their patients.  
The hardest part about my stay is not being able to practice my faith as usual, but everything else has been very good. The cleanliness on the ward is brilliant. The cleaning staff are brilliant coming round everyday giving the place a good scrub. The food is good but it can be a bit repetitive.  
The physio is absolutely amazing. For me personally, they have really helped me so much.  
I am very happy with my experience in Daisy Hill Hospital on the stroke/rehab ward.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Crescendo
title: Useful techniques for facing my fears
body:
I have been struggling with OCD ever since I was about 12 years old. My mental health gradually deteriorated to the point where I became completely debilitated when I was in my early 20s. I had to quit my job and I became extremely depressed. So I decided to seek professional help. The type of treatment that was recommended to me was CBT.  
The treatment commenced in 2022 and my therapist was almost immediately able to establish a sense of trust, and that allowed me to relax and open up about my problems. Initially we focused on issues regarding things like leaving the house, and she helped me to face my fears as opposed to avoiding them. Later on she noticed that there might be something else wrong with me and she suggested that I might also be autistic. So she advised me to read about the disorder and see if I can relate to it. After reading and hearing things about it I was almost certain that I had ASD. This revelation is perhaps the biggest takeaway from this course of therapy, as it allowed me to gain a much better understanding of who I am. I now realise that there is a large community of people that share the same problems and struggles that I have.  
My therapist also taught me how to do behaviour experiments, which was a useful technique that enabled me to face my fears and it allowed me to learn how to tolerate my anxiety. The service and care that I received could have been better in certain areas. My biggest dissatisfaction comes from the fact that there was never any continuity from session to session, and every week it seemed like we were starting from scratch.  
Overall, this is a service that I would very much recommend to anyone who is suffering from OCD or any kind of anxiety disorder. With a condition like OCD it is vital to put the appropriate interventions in place as early as possible, and not let it fester and eventually take over your life.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: septembergj58
title: Cataract consultation
body:
After being on the list at Elgin hospital for a year, I was given an appointment at the cataract clinic in ARI. We drove for 2 hours in horrendous weather, to get to the appointment. I arrived at the ward and reception was unmanned, so stood waiting with another 2 people who had entered just before me. A nurse came in and said to take a seat in the waiting area round the corner. I waited for over 30 minutes, then had notification of a voice-mail on my phone. I checked the voice mail, to find it was the ward asking why I had not turned up. I went back to reception, which was still unmanned, and a domestic assistant did her best to help. She came and advised me, that she had informed them I was in the waiting area all the time.  
Due to Covid masks had to be worn, which due to being claustrophobic, causes me severe anxiety. I waited a further 40 minutes, with still no-one coming near me, and could not sit with a mask on any longer, so had to get out. I had left home over 3 hours prior, and there was no water available, there was a coffee machine that was switched off. I told the receptionist I had been sitting waiting for 80 minutes, and just got what I found to be a very rude reply, after which my anxiety had escalated to the point I was having a panic attack, and I left the ward. I gave up and paid to have the surgery done privately the following month.  
I would also like to mention, I put in a complaint on the NHS complaints web-page which has not even been acknowledged

readBy.name: Aberdeen City Health & Social Care Partnership

author: Daria
title: Thank you for being so lovely and professional
body:
I had a gastroscopy today at Kings Mill Hospital. I just wanted to say how lovely and caring was all the staff.  
I was explained the whole procedure and what will happen. And also I wanted to say thank you for being so lovely and professional.  
Thank you once again

author: lacertajf37
title: 5 star service, excellent care from all staff
body:
Day surgery at University Hospital Wishaw.  
5 star service, excellent care from all staff

author: gammaqc44
title: Trying to make a referral to the community rehab team.
body:
My uncle fell on the stairs after not eating and drinking at home for 5 days. He has cancer and a heart condition.  
He had a hospital stay of around a week and was discharged home. He thought he was told a physio would visit him at home however that referral was not made before leaving hospital. He was also told to contact OT once he was home.  
After not hearing from anyone for 2 weeks I called North Ayrshire HSCP who said I had called the wrong team and they couldn’t transfer my call and to call Saltcoats Town Hall as that was the local service. I called Saltcoats Town Hall and they checked and advised there was no record of a referral and family members or service users cannot make referrals to the community rehab team only medical professionals and I needed to call the GP practice and gave me a number to call. I called the number given to be told they were the wrong GP practice and to call another number which I called to discover it was another Medical Group - in the same building with same reception team. They advised as he has been a recent inpatient the discharging consultant would need to make the referral.  
I called Crosshouse Hospital and asked to speak with the discharging consultants secretary and was put through. This secretary was on annual leave however another consultants secretary spoke with me, took the details and said they would pass it on. The discharging consultants secretary called me today, went over the information I had provided the day before and advised the consultant was on annual leave however they would discuss with another consultant. They then came back to advise there was no need for dietitian involvement as he was eating on the ward (reason for admission was fall due to no eating or drinking for 5 days so I think it’s reasonable to conclude that he eats well when nurses are prompting but less well at home). He was discharged from physio as he was mobilising on the ward.  
He was discharged home to a 2 story house with bed and bathroom upstairs. He has no equipment and significant 1 sided weakness following a road traffic accident around 40 years ago. There is only one bannister and he was not assessed on the stairs so I am not clear how the decision to discharge was made without assessment on the stairs. Again reason for admission was a collapse and fall down the stairs. The secretary agreed to try once more with the consultant however didn’t think it would work and advised me to try the GP again.  
At this point I’m stuck. My uncle is becoming frailer. As a family we have installed the bannister and got him the equipment he needs. I’ve asked community OT to request grab-rails which the duty OT done and hopefully these will be in soon. He continues to have poor balance, reduced strength and is starting to give up. It’s not a big ask for some physio and some dietician advice but I cannot work out how to make this happen.  
I am exceptionally frustrated and feel I am letting my uncle down.

readBy.name: North Ayrshire Health & Social Care Partnership
Office of Ruth Maguire ( Mp for Cunninghame South )

author: geminiqr38
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Great hospital care
body:
I have been in hospital since last Saturday. I was in HDU at first, then was moved to male surgical on Tuesday. Since I’ve arrived in male surgical everything has been good. The staff are very friendly and very helpful. They are so good. The staff are very attentive. The doctors are lovely. They have explained everything very thoroughly to me.  
The food isn’t the best, but at the end of the day it is hospital food.  
My first suggestion to improve the hospital, is that they need more staff. The staff are doing their best under the circumstances and conditions they work in, but they are extremely over worked and very underpaid for the job they do. And secondly the toilets on the ward should be cleaned more regularly. The cleaning staff have the ward itself immaculate, but I personally think the toilets should be cleaned every hourly.  
But the care I am receiving is very good.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Mixmatch
title: Very friendly and helpful staff who put me at ease
body: Admitted for day surgery at the beginning of March 2023. Very friendly and helpful staff who put me at ease. No complaints at all. Thank you

author: earthds87
title: Friendly care
body:
Since Tuesday last, after catheterisation, I have had nothing but the best friendliest care from the Troon District Nurses every day since. Hopefully they will get a break today.  
But it is very reassuring that they are there for any related issues.  
Praise highly and appreciated. Thank you

author: Elaine234
title: It was so relaxing and I felt so pampered
body:
After having a major surgery I was having a really down day feeling sorry for myself, laying in bed.  
I had a visit from Zoe who works with Beatson Cancer Charity, she did my nails and gave me a hand massage. It was so relaxing and I felt so pampered . She is such a lovely caring girl who totally turned my frown upside down.  
The service provided is wonderful I had no idea how much I actually needed it, so a massive thank you to Zoe and the Beatson Cancer Charity

author: Tersg66
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: A scary start but a pleasant stay
body: I have been in hospital since last week. I took a turn and woke up in Daisy Hill, it was very scary.Since coming on to female surgical everything has been excellent. The staff couldn’t be better to me. I have been treated so well. They really are brilliant and extremely helpful.The doctors are brilliant. They are very nice people and very clear how they explain everything to me.The food is lovely. They give you so much food. I wouldn’t eat the half of it at home.The cleaning/domestic staff are wonderful. They are so lovely and have the ward Immaculate.I am very happy with my stay.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: RedRobin
title: Their team approach and communication is exemplary.
body:
I have been accessing support from the Millbrook Team since December 2022 and the whole team are amazing and deserve an individual story about their amazing work (so more to follow).  
This one is dedicated to Diane for giving me a voice in a world where I have no speech and feel so isolated and scared - Diane and her manager Younis have made a significant difference to how I have handled the immense stress and their support has been invaluable.  
I had a Work Hearing meeting yesterday where they were considering dismissing me for lengthy sickness absence but with the support of the Team and especially Diane I was offered Convalescent Leave - this will make a huge difference to my thinking as I can now focus on getting well.  
My thanks to Kelly my Community Psychiatric Nurse (CPN) for referring me for the Employment Support Team.  
Kelly is an amazing and inspiring individual who's calm approach and care has enabled me to access that support and other support too - wish you could clone the team and spread them across the world as everyone deserves to be treated with the dignity and respect that I have.  
The team are all ultimate professionals and their team approach and communication is exemplary.  
[Unsure about 'Seeing the whole me']  
  
[Unsure about 'Being listened to']  
  
[Unsure about 'Involved in decisions']  
  
[Unsure about 'Being given time']  
  
[Unsure about 'Appointments']

author: eridanuspb57
title: The new appointment system
body: I was very frustrated with the old appointment system and was so relieved to hear you’re changing it. I have been able to make a face-to-face appointment with the GP of my choice for the following day! A huge improvement! Thank you!

author: earthds87
title: Lack of empathy and attention to patient needs
body:
I was brought in by ambulance last Tuesday with retention and as is the normal for this age, spent 3 hours in the ambulance outside and in excruciating pain.  
When I was transferred into ED cubicle 16. I was still in pain but nobody came to ask after my condition or tell me how long they thought it would be before a drain was inserted to relieve the pain.  
After the catheter insertion, the pressure was relieved but somebody forgot to tell my bladder! It was a level of 10+ and persistent in waves.  
For a period of time nobody came to ask after me, nor offer any refreshments. Then a doctor came by but their attitude all along was no empathy, no concern of the pain I was experiencing, just a desire for me to go home, despite my inability to walk pain-free.  
Unfortunately my OD prevented immediate discharge, and I was kept in longer. Although as for the observation, it was in name only. Nobody looked in regularly, not even a glass of water was on offer. My only refreshment was a meal brought in by a person I believe to be a domestic?I was very appreciative of that.  
The above mentioned doctor did come in but that was to do with my OD at the start and my recall is that the tone was never in a supportive way.  
I had never, nor would I expect preferential treatment, but I had thought those who knew me would offer some empathy and the same courtesy as you would any patient, when able to do so.  
Once I was ready to be discharged I had to arrange my own travel home, despite being in 10 + level pain.  
I felt my care after the catheter insertion was very detached, just leaving me in agony, not even attempting to relieve the pain.  
I feel this is not the level of care anybody should have to experience.

author: earthds87
title: Brilliant ambulance service
body:
I felt well looked after during transition and transfer, all crews in mid-March were brilliant.  
I send you my thanks .  
Hope your hanging around times decline soon. See some of you on my next shift post recovery.

author: earthds87
title: Excellent doctor in ED
body:
He was the first person I saw after being handed over by the ambulance crew into cubicle 16 at Ayr ED.  
Dr Rayad, I hope spelt correctly here, was surprised to see me and I felt offered genuine concern. His manner was very professional and he tried to be as painless as was possible with a catheterisation. I am grateful for the friendly face, and was disappointed that I had not been transferred earlier in that shift.

author: attendantfe37
title: My son's day surgery
body:
We attended the qeuh children’s hospital for my son to have day surgery for grommets and adenoids removed.  
My son is very young but also autistic so it was something I was really stressing over, how he would cope after some similar situations prior not having a very positive outcome.  
However, all staff, in particular the anaesthetist, blew me away. The accommodations, understanding and support was phenomenal. At one point the anaesthetist was on the floor playing with my son, on his level and completely taking in his actions and sensory issues and accommodating his plan going forward around these. It was honestly so refreshing and heartwarming to watch. The difference this made to us as a family was indescribable. I really want to say a huge thank you well done to all staff on day surgery ward.Thank you x

author: Dusgusted
title: Patient transport service cancellation
body:
Just received a telephone call from the above at 17:45 pm today cancelling a previously booked transport for Monday. I telephoned hospital transport and they explained that they had to cancel booking due to heavy demand.  
I am very heavily disabled and require significant support and assistance from the ambulance workers to even access the ambulance. I have cerebral palsy, quadruple bypass, insulin dependent diabetes and iretractable hiccoughs which can result in me losing the ability to breath for short periods of time. This means that any form of public transport is not an option for me. This is all on record all and to cancel at all, and at such short notice, outside office hours, with no option of appeal I find outrageous and unacceptable  
It is also on record that this is not a routine appointment and that the purpose is to discuss and agree the very real risks of proposed surgery with three booked consultants, some of whom have been brought in from other hospitals. I am not in a position to miss these appointments as I am no longer able to weight bear on my right leg and this has rendered me immobile even with my usual walking aids. I am therefore left with no alternative than to place myself at significant risk and find a way to get there.  
Could you please investigate asap?

author: defenderzb45
title: Wonderful hospital staff
body:
My mum was refered by her doctor to A and E. We arrived at the hospital and Scot was very attentive and caring, as he took me and my elderly motherly to MAU. My mum was a bit confused about what was happening and he was so caring and considerate.  
He took us to MAU, where Ashley took wonderful care of my mum. She was kind and considerate and kept us up to date of what was happening and why. She offered us a hot drink, and told us everything that would happen and what to expect. We felt taken care of.  
It was a long day, but Ashley and Scot, certainly made our experience as easy as possible. We would like to thank them for their kindness and care. I would add that all staff from porters to consultant were exceptionaly lovely. Thank you all.

author: susfd69
title: Eye appointment
body:
I had an appointment at the Outpatient Dept at the Health Centre, Trevaylor Rd, Falmouth,Cornwall. My appointment was on time and I had my pre-checks with two members of staff, one involved in eye checks and another taking blood pressure, pulse etc. The staff were lovely and put me at ease, giving me a lovely sense of well-being.  
I then had drops put into my eyes and returned to the waiting room for them to take effect before being called in to see the doctor on duty. The doctor gave my eyes a thorough examination, came up with a diagnosis and told me that I required further investigation at the main eye department of the Truro Hospital, Treliske. They would refer me. Also asked and answered any questions I had. The doctor's manner was good, very kind and understanding, and critical that I had been sent to them when I had no sign of cataracts.  
The only negative comment I would like to make is that I have had to wait since end of September for this appointment in February. That I should not have been referred to a clinic such as Falmouth that deals mainly with cataract cases, which I do not have, may be a mistake by my doctors surgery. Doctor also said that they hope after their referral that I will hear of an appointment in the next month as the issues they spotted with my eyes Uvitus should not be delayed, but addressed quickly.

author: Supernova88
title: Emotionally and physically worn down
body:
In February 2022 I woke up and the world was spinning around me the second I stepped out of bed. This was just the start of many horrendous and debilitating symptoms that I would gain and still to this day, I have no formal diagnosis and no real professional help.  
I am currently suffering from what I have been told informally is chronic urticaria and angioedema and hyperadrenic pots. I also believe I may have small fibre neuropathy and visual snow syndrome but the neurologist I saw said there was nothing wrong with me and again dismissed me.  
I have also recently found out that I have Hypermobile Ehler Danlos Syndrome which is massively related to these syndromes. I have never had such bad care than the care I have received at both Lincoln County Hospital and my surgery. I have been told this is all in my head and that it is anxiety. I have been spoken to like I’m a liar and told off for wasting their time. I now have to wait to see a cardiologist for testing and a diagnosis and I have to wait another 9 months. I have to take four antihistamines a day (I have no allergies) and there aren’t many foods that I don’t react to. I can only wash my hair once a week as my forehead becomes covered in hives and hurts so badly. I have been told by Leicester allergy service that they won’t accept my referral until I have taken four antihistamines a day for two months and then I still have an 18 week wait. I have already taken 3 antihistamines a day since December and it’s barely helped.  
Last night I lay on my bedroom floor and thought I am going to die. My skin felt like it was on fire, my throat was closing up and I was having horrendous adrenaline surges throughout the night. The only way to relieve the adrenaline slightly is to lie flat on the floor. This is my life most nights, I can’t sleep, I can’t rest or relax. It’s pure torture.  
I feel like my life is over, my beautiful children have lost their happy, mum and my husband has lost his soul mate.  
I am now suffering from anxiety and depression due to delayed diagnoses and any form of specialist help.  
We literally wouldn’t leave a dog like this so why is it that I have been left to feel so scared and alone. I have lost all trust in the NHS and I honestly don’t know how I can carry on.

title: Great care and support
body:
I would like to thank all the staff in Ruby Ward and Opal Ward and also the wider support team for the care and support to my daughter Zoe and to her family. From being contacted by the Adult Mental Health Team, conversations with her doctor and staff. We have felt listened to and 
included in Ward Rounds, to her aftercare and the fact she can stay until suitable accommodation is arranged. She’s happy, chatty and I’m so pleased to see her thriving. Huge thank you to everyone.

title: Beautiful people of the pain clinic
body: Had sacroiliac steroid injections for the first time. A restful experience in spite of having been so nervous. Too early yet to know whether the treatment will yield benefits but I cannot praise the theatre team highly enough. Thank you so much.

author: Mister D
title: Getting help for depression
body: Lost my mother 12 months ago,I was so close to her and have struggled to cope ever since,I have been  suffering with Depression and Anxiety,I contacted the bereavement service for some guidance on getting counselling and found them excellent to speak to and really helpful

author: Cricket toe guy
title: I really appreciated the quick response and understanding
body:
I came into Dunfermline Queen Margaret on a Friday night with an injured big toe.  
I saw Fiona who quickly sent me off for an xray and then later did a procedure to relieve the pressure on my toe. Fiona was fantastic, she was very attentive and reassuring.  
I really appreciated the quick response and understanding of Fiona and the team at Minor Injuries.

author: Karl234
title: Partial Knee replacement
body:
Had a knee replacement.  
From the surgeons to all the staff.  
Made me feel comftable and reassured.  
My only concern is I didn't have long enough in.  
Other than that the nurses were fantastic.

author: Janexc67
title: The road to recovery after my stroke
body:
I arrived at the rehab hospital unable to stand after a stroke and I'm now climbing stairs! I thought I would never walk again but the whole team have been amazing. They have encouraged me so much since my arrival and going to the gym and all the extra activities such as cookery and singing have been fun and helped me to cope with the effects of having a stroke.  
I also feel a lot stronger physically and mentally and I am gradually getting my independence back. A very big thank you to all the physios, psychologists and occupational therapists doctors nurses and healthcare assistants.

title: Excellent
body:
Been to WGH 5 times in 18 months...High blood pressure mainly with heart irregularity...could not have been more professional! Each visit I made was thoroughly attended to from begining to the end with such caring professional staff...every stage and result of blood tests etc was explained so I would know what was happening. Not once did I feel a nuisance and the staff go above and beyond to make you feel happy and safe...from the cleaning staff to the doctors who are a great bunch and very gentle loving kind and professional...my only complaint was the food! 
..thank you to WGH...

author: septemberpe84
title: Care for my son
body:
Shortly after my son was born it was noticed that his testicles were firmer than expected. After a few different professional opinions and an ultrasound, it was found that he had testicular torsion and one of his testicles had died.  
As there was hope of saving the second testicle he was blue lighted down to Bristol children's hospital where he went straight into surgery. Unfortunately we weren't able to travel with him. It was incredibly scary leaving out brand new baby with strangers and knowing that he was in surgery despite only being a few hours old. The surgery went as expected and they weren't able to save the second testicle.  
He then spent 2 nights in intensive care where he had a feeding tube and was oxygen as a result of the surgery. By Tuesday we were transferred back to Musgrove which meant we were closer to home. He still needed oxygen and stayed in hospital for a further 4 days before returning home fit and healthy.

readBy.name: University Hospitals Bristol and Weston NHS Foundation Trust

author: Shagq75
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: The NHS's best example of staff is in stroke
body:
The ward is excellent. The other patients are entertaining and help pass the time by keeping me occupied throughout the day. The ward is really clean, and it's nice to see that the domestic staff is always present. There is always someone on hand to wipe up spills as soon as they occur. I must say that I was pleasantly surprised by how wonderful the food was.  
The staff is exceptional, and I am amazed at how they manage when their work since it is so demanding. I simply could not handle what they go through every day and then return to work the next day.  
The NHS's best example of staff is in stroke.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Jimjp64
title: Pain free cataract removal
body:
Excellent,  
I was met at reception right on time, taken to the Cataract Unit QMH Dunfermline  
I was nervous, but was put at my ease by every staff member - I was dealt with the utmost respect and kindness by all.  
A nurse explained to me what she was doing and why, confirmed my records name etc and placed bands on my wrist. Another nurse, came double checked and fully told me of what would happen and when  
Then the surgeon came to me and spend a lot of their time assuring me of what was to happen and how. I then signed the permission document for Cataract Removal and replacement of lens. They marked which eye was to be done with a marker on my forehead, meanwhile other nurses administered various eye drops, one to dilate my pupil, others as local anaesthetic. All this took place between 08:00 and 08:20,  
Then a Nurse took me 20 yards to the operating theatre, I was to lay on a op table. It was very comfortable, the Surgeon advised what was to happen.  
Their was NO pain No uncomfortable feelings, just a bright light that was fine. Fifteen minutes later, it was done  
Whilst in the theatre, staff had contacted my escort (daughter) to advise that:  
A. I was in theatre, and  
B. It was complete and I could be collected in ten minutes  
I sat for about five minutes felt good and I was given an after care pack, and what and when I had to do further over a four week period  
The whole procedure was over in less than 45 minutes and we were then back home having a cuppa  
All the staff were kind and I was well informed at all times  
Thank you to all at the QMH  
To improve nothing really except to try and advise people the op is not what "we" imagine (a Scapel advancing on your eyeball slicing it open and tweezers sliding out the old lens and inserting a replacement then stitching it up). Nothing like that at all - it is painless, not even uncomfortable and all over 45 mins max.  
THANK YOU

author: Dneuve23
title: My son, who is gentle and lovely, felt ambushed
body:
The Asheton team visited suddenly due to Whitfield counselling Centre over reacting (but I get it, as an ex-experienced and highly trained nurse).  
My son is non-aggressive, just very low. He is kind, he annoyingly puts his friends before his own happiness. He has ASD, ADHD, POTS, hypermobility of joints, sleep apnoea.  
The sudden visit made my son feel ambushed. 2 doctors (no threat to anyone by son ever, or to myself). An awful nurse.  
Their opening gambit was: well speak to him then, and you are not on top of this at all, are you? Bearing mind I have been my sons constant (alone) since they were 3 and 6 yrs.  
I felt they were truly awful.

readBy.name: Kent and Medway NHS and Social Care Partnership Trust

author: Shagq75
title: Getting better as a result of the excellent treatment offered here.
body:
I must say that the treatment on stroke is great. You are treated with respect and given the impression that they are prioritising you. You feel as though you are a part of your care as they involve you in the process. I believe I'm getting better as a result of the excellent treatment offered here. The ward is always clean since it is always visible that cleaners are at work there.  
The employees are pleasant and allow you enough time to speak with them. Although I wouldn't want to wear a mask for as long as they do during their 12-hour shift, they must actually love what they do.  
The stroke staff are tough.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

title: Poor practice
body: Arrived there with ambulance for query sepsis. Tachycardic and overpyrexial (41 degrees), with dizziness, feeling sick, headache. Been there for about 10 hours and left shivering on a chair. There are at least two triage rooms but used for something else and not to assessing the patients based on the severity or care and monitoring requirements. They either don't know or don't care what triage rooms are for. They seems to don't know what medical emergencies are. Or to don't care.

The staff have been great and have really been a great support system knowing if i need anything they are helpful.  The foods been alright at times isnt a s good as others but its not awful and is edible

author: Someone with a tooth that broke exposing nerve
title: Emergency Dental helpline NHS
body:
I was one of the patients who lost NHS dental services when my practice closed. I am on a waiting list for NHS Dentist in Dumfries several miles away from where I live. On experiencing severe acute dental pain I called Emergency Dental Line for assistance. I am someone who only uses NHS when I need it.  
I ration myself and have only once seen a GP since I arrived in area 5 years. I was called about 08:30 person answering phone didn't seem to believe I was in severe pain and couldn't close my mouth. They suggested I have something to eat which told me they hadn't heard what I'd explained. The whole experience has shaken my confidence in dental services in NHS Dumfries & Galloway.  
I ended up having to terminate my interaction with the Emergency Dental Helpline and drive 90 miles to access a NHS dentist in another health board area who explained that a healthy tooth had cracked over a nerve and that was why I was in agony. This meant I had to have a day sick leave from my work to get to dentist and means I am thinking of leaving Dumfries and Galloway for somewhere with satisfactory NHS dental services.

title: Unprofessional, Violates Patient Confidentiality,…
body: I attended an appointment at this clinic on 13/03/2023, I spoke to the Receptionists who asked me of my medical issue and I did not want to tell them because they are not the doctors, so I told them it's private and they replied with "We need to know your issue", this made me feel very emotional and anxious, I had to tell them my medical issue in front of many patients which was embarrassing and they had the nerve to say it out loud. I was very embarrassed since this was a private matter, then I was called to see the doctor, who was only a clinician and I had specifically asked to see a Doctor. title: Alcohol detoxification
body:
All of the staff have been fantastic all the way through my journey. The first two days of my stay have been the hardest. I felt good in the middle part of my journey due to the medication I was on. Once the medication stopped, I was starting to climb the walls and wanting to get home. Whilst I was going through this, the staff talked me through it. All the staff have been amazing. I am very grateful to have experienced my Detox at the Dame Carol Detox Service. In particular Alan the Nurse was very supportive on my arrival along with Kerry the Recovery Worker who also helped me throughout my stay.  
I can't put into words, how grateful I am to all the staff. I have been given my life back.

author: Shagq75
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Kind and genuinely concerned for your wellbeing
body:
Everything is going according to schedule, I'm starting to feel better, and respiratory is doing fantastic. The portions they offer in each dish are always packed to fill me up, and the food has been okay. Although the surroundings are pleasant, some people could feel them to be too hot or chilly although I am at a nice temperature.  
The staff is incredibly kind and genuinely concerned for your wellbeing. It makes you feel like a real person when they have fun while checking on you, I like that. They take the time to make sure I understand everything and they don't make me feel bad for asking as many questions as I need to because they are aware of how busy they are.  
Respiratory really are doing a great job.
